questions.question_text: Your organization needs to ensure that the Google Cloud resources of each of your departments are segregated from one another. Each department has several environments of its own: development, testing, and production. Which strategy should your organization choose?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Its will be B. Organization > Folder > Project > Resource

comments.content: today , this question was asked in exam

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The recommended strategy for ensuring segregation of Google Cloud resources for each department with multiple environments (development, testing, and production) would be to create a folder per department, and create a project per environment in each folder.

This strategy provides a clear and organized structure for managing resources. By creating a folder per department, you can logically group projects and enforce access controls and policies at the folder level. Within each folder, you can then create separate projects for each environment (development, testing, and production). This allows for better isolation and control of resources within each environment.

Selected Answer: B
Option B (Create a folder per department and a project per environment in each folder) is the best choice because it provides a clear separation between departments and ensures strong isolation of environments within each department.

questions.question_text: Your organization is defining the resource hierarchy for its new application in Google Cloud. You need separate development and production environments. The production environment will be deployed in Compute Engine in two regions. Which structure should your organization choose?

choices.C: Create one project for the development environment and one project for the production environment.
choices.A: Create a single project for all environments. Use labels to segregate resources by environment.
choices.D: Create two projects for the development environment and two projects for the production environment (one for each region).
choices.B: Create a single project for all environments. Use tags to segregate resources by environment.

discussion.content: C is easier and you won't get less than D. I think creating one project per region wouldn't create benefit.

Selected Answer: C
The recommended structure for your organization's resource hierarchy in Google Cloud would be C. Create one project for the development environment and one project for the production environment.

This structure provides clear separation between the development and production environments, allowing for better management and control of resources. By having separate projects, you can enforce different access controls, configurations, and deployments for each environment. This ensures that changes made in the development environment do not impact the production environment.

Option A and B suggest using a single project for all environments and relying on labels or tags to segregate resources. While labels and tags can be useful for organizing and categorizing resources, they may not provide the same level of isolation and control as separate projects.

Option D suggests creating multiple projects for each environment, with separate projects for the development and production environments in each region. While this approach could work, it may introduce unnecessary complexity, especially if the two regions have similar configurations and requirements.

Selected Answer: D
Question is not well defined. Both C and D can be the answer. If you require simplicity and ease of mgmt, C is correct. For more granular control regarding regional compliance, access rights mgmt , billing etc. use D.

Selected Answer: C
If your organization accidentally purchased a 1-year Committed Use Discount (CUD) instead of the intended 3-year CUD you can reach out to Google Cloud Support as soon as possible to explain the situation and request assistance. They can guide you through the process and provide options for resolving the issue.

If the purchase is recent and you haven't started using the committed usage, you may have the option to cancel the 1-year CUD and repurchase the 3-year CUD.

questions.question_text:
Your organization runs a distributed application in the Compute Engine virtual machines. Your organization needs redundancy, but it also needs extremely fast communication (less than 10 milliseconds) between the parts of the application in different virtual machines.
Where should your organization locate this virtual machines?

discussion.content: I chose B since it guarantees a latency of ~10 milliseconds is maintained, well also giving the redundancy of multi-zone. If it was D, we could not guarantee 10 milliseconds between the different regions.

Selected Answer: B
Multi zone is also redundant within the region and it provides the lowest latency.

Selected Answer: B
Explanation:
Low-latency communication (<10ms) requires geographic proximity between virtual machines.
Using different zones within a single region ensures high availability and redundancy while keeping the network latency minimal.
Google Cloud's internal network allows low-latency communication between zones in the same region, making it the optimal choice.
Why the other options are incorrect?
❌ A. In a single zone within a single region – No redundancy; failure in that zone could take down the application.
❌ C. In multiple regions, using one zone per region – Inter-region communication typically has higher latency (>10ms), making it unsuitable.
❌ D. In multiple regions, using multiple zones per region – Adds redundancy but increases latency and complexity, making it inefficient for fast communication.

Selected Answer: B
Redundancy + Low latency

Selected Answer: B
To ensure redundancy and extremely fast communication (less than 10 milliseconds) between VMs, place them in different zones within a single region. This setup maintains low latency while providing fault tolerance.

Selected Answer: D
Gonna go with D even though C is also valid because distributing across regions and zones is recommended.
Answer is B
Answer B

Selected Answer: B
Options A, C, and D involve spreading the virtual machines across different configurations, such as single zone, multiple regions with one zone per region, or multiple zones per region. While these options may offer redundancy to some extent, they might not guarantee the desired extremely fast communication due to potential increased latency between different regions or zones.
Therefore B

B is correct

Selected Answer: C
To allow a production job running on a Compute Engine instance group to have access to a BigQuery dataset, you should include the service account associated with the Compute Engine instance group to the IAM policy of the BigQuery dataset. The service account represents the Compute Engine instances and is used to authenticate the job's access to the dataset.

By including the service account associated with the Compute Engine instance group in the IAM policy and granting the appropriate BigQuery roles or permissions, you ensure that the production job running on the Compute Engine instances has the necessary access to the BigQuery dataset.

Selected Answer: C
